"Carbon dioxide is good for the planet, it is food for all plants."

Carbon dioxide is, in fact, good for the planet, but too much of it can be 
very harmful; it disrupts the Earth's ability to re-radiate heat from the 
sun back into space. This causes an increase in temperature throughout the 
entire Earth's atmosphere, and explains why countries all over the world 
are getting more heatwaves over the years. 

As for carbon dioxide being food for plants, you are right. But what 
happens when you have too much CO2? Turns out plants grow faster, larger, 
and thus, produce more oxygen and pollen. This could be an issue for people 
with asthma, allergies, and other respiratory problems.

On the issue of global warming, I sincerely doubt the voracity of the 
claims politicians make regarding positive change on this issue.  Let's set 
aside the question of whether it is a serious issue or not for the moment, 
and assume that one were to believe (whether correctly or incorrectly) that 
it was.  Though capitalism, consumerism, and overpopulation are often seen 
as the culprits of this problem -- from where could you hope to find a 
solution?  Capitalism.  The free market will adapt to fill the demand, 
assuming of course, that legislation does not interfere with this process. 
 Any politician truly serious about creating change would proffer 
undeniable proof of a serious problem and create a demand for the desired 
outcome.  This aspect of proof is the key here.  When a politician cries 
wolf enough times, nobody could or should believe anything they say.  Their 
ability to create a demand and promote change is undermined.  The question 
is, who can you trust to give you honest, factual, and completely unbiased 
proof?  Is it the inevitable nature of politics to cry wolf?  The real 
problem is not so much the idea of capitalism, but the necessity of 
politicians.﻿

Regarding carbon dioxide in plants...

There is a maximum amount of carbon dioxide that can be absorbed before 
something else becomes a rate limiting factor.  For instance, you need 
glucose and oxygen for respiration to occur in your body and produce the 
energy necessary to function.  You need more energy when you are 
running (assuming you are using aerobic respiration).  The faster you run, 
the more you require.  Let's say I have given you all the oxygen you need 
and all the glucose you need in your body, you still cannot run any faster 
and will get tired because other factors are at play.  At a molecular level 
there are rates of reaction and optimum factors for enzymes etc. 

Photosynthesis rate is limited by sunlight (it only happens when there is 
enough light), water availability and plenty of other factors.  Carbon 
dioxide absorption from the atmosphere is only used when the plant needs it 
and is controlled by a concentration gradient.  A graph of rate of reaction 
against carbon dioxide absorption may be directly proportional up to a 
point, where the graph levels off, at which point it demonstrates another 
rate limiting factor. 

Moving on, you must not forget that the carbon cycle is a cycle, so there 
will never be a point where carbon dioxide runs out.  What can happen 
however, is carbon dioxide can be stuck in the upper atmosphere for decades 
if not hundreds of years, since we rely on trees and plants to 
absorb this.  The forests are what absorb our carbon dioxide output but we 
are putting far more out than they can absorb in so there is an 
accumulation (kind of like the US debt situation). 

The rate at which we are carrying out deforestation has affected balance 
and so our carbon dioxide "sponge" is getting smaller and smaller.  You can 
do your bit by ensuring you use paper made from sustainable forests (for 
each tree they cut down they plant at least one more), and saving energy in 
the home (not just for financial reasons, but realise this is for 
environmental ones too).  Spread the message.

Btw; I'm a science teacher :-)

Oh, and in case you didn't know, as the temperature of a body of water 
increases, the amount of CO2 it can hold in solution decreases. So a 
natural byproduct of increasing temperature, especially in the oceans, is a 
rise in the atmospheric and surface water CO2 levels.

The President's speech is chock full of the "carbon pollution" mistake. 
Does he not know that it is not carbon (which is soot, graphite and 
diamonds) but is carbon dioxide, only one of thousands of compounds of 
carbon, compounds that include PCBs and the constituents of our own bodies.
Calling the gas “carbon” encourages people to think of it as something 
‘dirty’, like graphite or soot. Calling CO2 by its proper name would help 
people remember that it is an invisible gas essential to plant 
photosynthesis.

We are actually near the lowest level of CO2 in Earth’s history. During a 
multi-million year period around 440 million years ago, CO2 was about 1400% 
(in other words, 14 times) today’s level while Earth was stuck in the 
coldest period of the last half-billion years. The climate models’ 
assumption that temperature is driven by CO2 is clearly wrong.
 
It is also important to recognize that commercial greenhouse operators 
routinely run their internal atmospheres at up to 1500 ppm CO2. This is 
more than four times Bill McKibben’s so-called safe limit. Yet there is no 
hint of any consequent temperature rise, while the plants inside grow far 
more efficiently than at the 400 ppm in the outside atmosphere. This is not 
surprising. Grade school students understand that CO2 is plant food and so 
anything but “carbon pollution” as Obama and the EPA Administrator wrongly 
label it. In fact, CO2 concentrations in submarines can reach levels well 
above 10,000 ppm, thirty times the “safe” limit, with no harmful effects to 
the crew.﻿

Hotter average global temperatures mean more heat waves, more wildfires, 
and faster evaporation leading to more drought. But it also means more 
moisture in the atmosphere, so precipitation becomes heavier when it does 
come, and wetter areas become wetter while dry areas become drier. Sea 
levels rise from ice melt at the poles and cyclones become stronger from 
the oceans’ rising heat content, leading to more flooding and storm damage 
on the coasts. The poles heat up faster than the equator, destabilizing 
global weather patterns. Species and ecosystems collapse on both land and 
sea as climate change and ocean acidification alter their habitats. Crop 
production and food supplies are upended, fresh water becomes harder to 
come by, and vectors for pests and disease increase. Basically, rising 
global temperatures shift the range of possible weather so that destructive 
and extreme events become more likely.

The problem with thorium plants (e.g. LFTRs) is somewhat due to the cost of 
building new plants/refitting old ones, but mostly due to the fact that in 
the decay chain of thorium nuclear fuel there is U-233, which is 
weapons-grade materials. In other words, every sizable thorium plant would 
contain enough weapons-grade material to manufacture dirty nuclear bombs 
with ease if a terrorist or other group desired to do so, and sufficiently 
protecting each power plant would be economically impractical.

That said, I'm not bashing nuclear power; rather, Uranium technology we 
have now is completely fine and should be promoted to the fullest extent. I 
never quite understood public fear of nuclear fuel byproducts, since they 
are produced in much smaller volumes and are actually less dangerous than 
the toxic ash that accumulates in coal power plants which we seem less 
intent on shutting down.

The President's speech is chock full of the "carbon pollution" mistake. 
Does he not know that it is not carbon (which is soot, graphite and 
diamonds) but is carbon dioxide, only one of thousands of compounds of 
carbon, compounds that include PCBs and the constituents of our own bodies.

Calling the gas “carbon” encourages people to think of it as something 
‘dirty’, like graphite or soot. Calling CO2 by its proper name would help 
people remember that it is an invisible gas essential to plant 
photosynthesis.

We are actually near the lowest level of CO2 in Earth’s history. During a 
multi-million year period around 440 million years ago, CO2 was about 1400% 
(in other words, 14 times) today’s level while Earth was stuck in the 
coldest period of the last half-billion years. The climate models’ 
assumption that temperature is driven by CO2 is clearly wrong.
 
It is also important to recognize that commercial greenhouse operators 
routinely run their internal atmospheres at up to 1500 ppm CO2. This is 
more than four times Bill McKibben’s so-called safe limit. Yet there is no 
hint of any consequent temperature rise, while the plants inside grow far 
more efficiently than at the 400 ppm in the outside atmosphere. This is not 
surprising. Grade school students understand that CO2 is plant food and so 
anything but “carbon pollution” as Obama and the EPA Administrator wrongly 
labels it. In fact, CO2 concentrations in submarines can reach levels well 
above 10,000 ppm, thirty times the “safe” limit, with no harmful effects to 
the crew.﻿
